quiz.title: Algebra 2: Unit 9 Quiz 7
quiz.subtitle: 9.7: The Fundamental Counting Principle
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Using multiplication to find the total number of possibilities

questions.question: A standard computer password must be 8 characters long. If it can use any of the 26 lowercase letters and 10 digits, and repetitions are allowed, how many passwords are possible?
questions.explanation: There are 26 letters + 10 digits = 36 total options for each of the 8 slots. Using the Fundamental Counting Principle, this is $36 \times 36 \times 36 \times 36 \times 36 \times 36 \times 36 \times 36$, or $36^8$.

questions.question: A restaurant offers 5 appetizers, 8 main courses, and 3 desserts. How many different three-course meals are possible?
questions.explanation: Using the Fundamental Counting Principle: $5 \times 8 \times 3 = 120$ different meals.

questions.question: A license plate has 3 letters followed by 4 digits. How many different plates are possible if letters and digits can be repeated?
questions.explanation: 26 choices for each letter ($26^3$) and 10 choices for each digit ($10^4$). $26^3 \times 10^4 = 17,576 \times 10,000 = 175,760,000$.

questions.question: You have 4 shirts, 3 pairs of pants, and 2 pairs of shoes. How many different outfits can you make?
How many 5-digit PIN codes can be created using digits 0-9 if digits cannot be repeated?
questions.explanation: First digit: 10 choices, second: 9, third: 8, fourth: 7, fifth: 6. $10 \times 9 \times 8 \times 7 \times 6 = 30,240$.

questions.question: A quiz has 4 true/false questions. How many different answer keys are possible for this quiz?
questions.explanation: Each question has 2 possibilities (T or F). For 4 questions: $2 \times 2 \times 2 \times 2 = 2^4 = 16$.

questions.question: A local area code has 3 digits. The first digit cannot be 0 or 1. How many different area codes are possible if the other digits can be any number 0-9?
questions.explanation: The first digit has 8 options (2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9). The second and third digits each have 10 options. $8 \times 10 \times 10 = 800$.

questions.question: A pizza place offers 3 crust types, 4 sauces, and 8 toppings. How many one-topping pizzas are possible?
How many different 3-letter codes can be made from the letters A, B, C, D if letters cannot be repeated?
questions.explanation: First letter: 4 choices, second: 3 choices, third: 2 choices. $4 \times 3 \times 2 = 24$.

questions.question: A student is scheduling 4 classes: Math, English, Science, and History. If they can take these in any order during the first 4 periods of the day, how many different schedules are possible?
questions.explanation: This is a permutation of 4 items: $4 \times 3 \times 2 \times 1 = 24$ different possible schedules.

scoreMessages.70: Good work. Remember: multiply each independent choice!
scoreMessages.50: Keep practicing. Draw tree diagrams if it helps visualize.
scoreMessages.0: The Fundamental Counting Principle is all about multiplication. Try again!
